articles.title: Subject matter and scope
articles.summary: This Directive lays down measures to achieve high common level of cybersecurity across the Union.
requirements: Apply to essential and important entities
Apply to public administration entities
Cover cybersecurity risk management and reporting obligations

articles.title: Scope
articles.summary: This Directive applies to public and private entities of a type listed in Annex I or II.
requirements: Apply to essential entities (Annex I)
Apply to important entities (Annex II)
Member States may include additional sectors

articles.title: Sectors and entities
articles.summary: Essential entities include: energy, transport, banking, financial market infrastructures, health, drinking water, waste water, digital infrastructure, ICT service management, public administration, space.
requirements: Identify entities in Annex I sectors (essential)
Identify entities in Annex II sectors (important)

articles.title: National cybersecurity strategies
articles.summary: Member States shall adopt national cybersecurity strategy defining strategic objectives, governance framework, and measures.
requirements: Define strategic objectives and priorities
Establish governance framework
Identify measures relating to preparedness, response and recovery
Promote cybersecurity culture and cyber hygiene
Address security of supply chains
Foster coordinated vulnerability disclosure
Review strategy at least every five years

articles.title: National competent authorities
articles.summary: Member States shall designate one or more national competent authorities on NIS.
requirements: Designate at least one competent authority
Notify Commission of designated authorities
Ensure authorities have adequate resources and expertise

articles.title: Computer Security Incident Response Teams (CSIRTs)
articles.summary: Member States shall designate one or more CSIRTs.
requirements: Designate at least one CSIRT
Ensure CSIRT has adequate resources, premises, infrastructure
Ensure CSIRT operates under clear legal mandate
CSIRT tasks: monitor incidents, issue early warnings, respond to incidents, participate in CSIRT network

domains.title: Chapter IV - Cybersecurity Risk Management and Reporting Obligations

articles.title: Cybersecurity risk-management measures
articles.summary: Essential and important entities shall take appropriate and proportionate technical, operational and organisational measures to manage cybersecurity risks.
requirements: Implement policies on risk analysis and information system security
Implement incident handling procedures
Implement business continuity and crisis management
Implement supply chain security (including security-related aspects of supplier relationships)
Implement security in network and information systems acquisition, development and maintenance
Implement policies and procedures to assess effectiveness of cybersecurity risk-management measures
Implement basic cyber hygiene practices and cybersecurity training
Implement policies and procedures regarding use of cryptography and encryption
Implement human resources security, access control policies and asset management
Implement multi-factor authentication or continuous authentication, secured voice, video and text communications, and secured emergency communication systems

articles.title: Reporting obligations
articles.summary: Essential and important entities shall notify CSIRT or competent authority of significant incidents without undue delay and within 24 hours of becoming aware.
requirements: Early warning notification: within 24 hours of becoming aware (if applicable)
Incident notification: within 72 hours, including initial assessment (severity, impact, indicators of compromise)
Intermediate report: upon request, to update initial notification
Final report: within one month of incident notification, including detailed description, severity, impact, type of threat, applied and ongoing mitigation measures, cross-border impact
Report significant incidents affecting network and information systems
No reporting required if incident below significance threshold set by Member State

articles.title: Use of European vulnerability databases
articles.summary: Member States and entities may use European vulnerability databases established at Union level.
requirements: Encourage use of EU vulnerability databases
Contribute vulnerability information where appropriate

articles.title: Coordinated vulnerability disclosure
articles.summary: Member States shall establish coordinated vulnerability disclosure policies and ensure publication.
requirements: Establish vulnerability disclosure policy
Publish disclosure policy
Ensure policy addresses how vulnerabilities can be reported
Ensure timely remediation of reported vulnerabilities

articles.title: Responsible disclosure of vulnerabilities
articles.summary: Member States shall ensure that natural and legal persons can report vulnerabilities to manufacturer without facing legal consequences.
requirements: Protect security researchers who report vulnerabilities in good faith
Ensure no legal liability for good faith vulnerability disclosure

domains.title: Chapter VI - Jurisdiction, Penalties and Enforcement

articles.title: Jurisdiction
articles.summary: Member States shall ensure that essential and important entities providing services in the Union are subject to jurisdiction.
requirements: Establish jurisdiction over entities established in Member State
Establish jurisdiction over entities offering services in Member State
Designate representative for entities not established in EU

articles.title: Ex-post supervision by competent authorities
articles.summary: Competent authorities shall conduct ex-post supervision including on-site inspections and off-site supervision.
requirements: Conduct regular on-site inspections
Conduct off-site supervision activities
Request information and documentation
Require entities to undergo security audits
Issue binding instructions

articles.title: Administrative penalties
articles.summary: Member States shall lay down rules on penalties for infringements, including administrative fines.
requirements: Essential entities - maximum fines: at least €10,000,000 or 2% of total worldwide annual turnover (whichever higher)
Important entities - maximum fines: at least €7,000,000 or 1.4% of total worldwide annual turnover (whichever higher)
Consider: nature, gravity, duration of infringement, intentional or negligent character, actions to mitigate damage, degree of cooperation
Ensure penalties are effective, proportionate and dissuasive

articles.title: Penalties for infringement by management
articles.summary: Member States shall ensure management body may be held liable for infringements.
requirements: Hold management body liable for breaching obligations
Temporarily ban management from performing duties in case of serious infringement

articles.title: Cooperation Group
articles.summary: Cooperation Group composed of representatives of Member States, Commission and ENISA to support and facilitate strategic cooperation and exchange of information.
requirements: Participate in Cooperation Group
Exchange information on implementation of Directive
Share best practices on cybersecurity

articles.title: CSIRTs network
articles.summary: CSIRTs network to contribute to development of confidence and trust, ensure effective cooperation, support rapid and effective operational cooperation.
requirements: Participate in CSIRTs network
Exchange information on incidents
Share situational awareness information
Coordinate responses to cross-border incidents

articles.title: European cyber crises liaison organisation network (EU-CyCLONe)
articles.summary: EU-CyCLONe to support coordinated management of large-scale cybersecurity incidents and crises.
requirements: Participate in EU-CyCLONe
Share information during large-scale incidents
Coordinate crisis response at Union level

domains.title: Chapter VIII - Security Requirements for Supply Chain

articles.title: Supply chain security
articles.summary: Entities shall address security in supply chain including security-related aspects of relationships with suppliers and service providers.
requirements: Assess cybersecurity risks in supply chain
Include cybersecurity requirements in supplier contracts
Monitor supplier compliance with cybersecurity requirements
Address vulnerabilities in supply chain
Ensure supplier incident reporting obligations
Implement measures to ensure continuity of service delivery

domains.title: Chapter IX - Information and Experience Sharing

articles.title: Information sharing arrangements
articles.summary: Member States shall encourage essential and important entities to voluntarily notify relevant information sharing and analysis centres.
requirements: Encourage voluntary participation in information sharing
Facilitate sharing of technical details about cybersecurity threats and incidents
Protect confidentiality of shared information

annexI.title: Essential Entities
sectors: Energy (electricity, district heating and cooling, oil, gas, hydrogen)

Health sector (healthcare providers, EU reference laboratories, entities manufacturing medical devices/in vitro diagnostic medical devices, pharmaceutical manufacturers, entities researching and developing pharmaceuticals)

Digital infrastructure (internet exchange points, DNS service providers, TLD name registries, cloud computing service providers, data centre service providers, content delivery networks, trust service providers, public electronic communications networks, publicly available electronic communications services)
ICT service management (managed service providers, managed security service providers)
Space (ground-based infrastructure operated by space sector entities)

annexII.title: Important Entities
sectors: Manufacture, production and distribution of chemicals
Manufacturing (medical devices, in vitro diagnostic medical devices, computer and electronics, machinery and equipment, motor vehicles and transport equipment, other manufacturing)
Digital providers (online marketplaces, online search engines, social networking service platforms)
